content.text:
To get the sum of the numbers in an array in one fell swoop:

var numbers = [1, 2, 3];
var sum = numbers.reduce((a, cv) => a + cv, 0); // sum = 6

The reduce function takes a callback and an initial value.
a: accumulator
cv: current value

data.title: Pythagorean Triples - Values for a, b, and c

content.text:
For a^2 and b^2, any square >= 9 will work. This is because, for any such square, there exists a square whose top and side it can be wrapped around. For example 9 wraps around 16. Every odd square a^2 will wrap around the even square computed as the square of (a^2 - 1) / 2. Likewise, every even square will wrap around a square computed as the square of (a^2 - 4) / 2. In this case, there is a triple with c - b = 2, for which a^2 is the sum of 2b+1 (inner layer) and 2b+3) outer layer, or 4b + 4.

So given an odd square as a^2, subtract 1 and divide by 2 to find a value for b. Given an even square as a^2, subtract 4 and divide by 4 to get a value for b. We've looked at 9; let's consider 25, for a = 5. Calculating (25 - 1) / 2 yields 12 for the value of b, whose square is 144. Therefore c^2 = 25  + 144 = 169, yielding 13 as the value of c. The resulting triple is (5, 12, 13).

An example with an even square is a = 8, a^2 = 64. Take (64 - 4) / 4, which is 15. The square of 15 is 225. So a^2 + b^2 = 64 + 225, which yields 289 as the value of c^2, so c = 17. The triple is (8, 15, 17).

So for a and b, any square >= 9 will work. What about for c? 

The first value of c for which c^2 can be expressed as the sum of two other squares is 5, for the familiar (3, 4, 5) triple. The next value of c that works is 10 (6, 8, 10), followed by 13 (5, 12, 13). The squares 36, 49, 64, and 81 cannot be expressed as the sum of two squares. This is true of more than half of the possible values of c from 5 - 100.

It's not apparent that there's any way to determine whether a given square will work as c^2, other than by testing it to see if it can be expressed as the sum of two squares. The approach I use is to compute the sum of its layers until I either find a square or run out of layers. The outermost layer is 2c - 1. The next is 2c - 3, then 2c - 5, &c.

content.definition: The painting of distasteful or sordid subjects. Also: writing about distasteful or sordid subjects.
content.etymology: Etymology: < classical Latin rhyparographos painter of low or sordid subjects (see rhyparograph n.) + -y suffix3; compare -graphy comb. form. Compare later rhypography n.
content.citations: 1678 E. Phillips New World of Words (new ed.) List Barbarous Words Ryparography. 1842 W. Smith Dict. Greek & Rom. Antiq. 694/1 Rhyparography, pornography, and all the lower classes of art. 1850 J. Leitch tr. K. O. Müller Ancient Art (new ed.) §163 At this time also rhyparography (so-called still life) probably made its appearance. 1896 G. Saintsbury Hist. 19th Cent. Lit. i. 22 The Lousiad (a perfect triumph of cleverness expended on what the Greeks called rhyparography). 1927 Amer. Mercury May p. xlviii Mr. Craven cannot quite distinguish between painting and art, rhyparography and art, realism and art. 1951 M. L. Wolf Dict. Arts 586 Rhyparography, (1) In literature, esp. Renaissance, the presentation of sordid or low individuals or subjects. (2) In art generally, esp. painting, the depiction of foul or revolting objects or scenes; also, the painting of genre or still life pictures. 2007 R. Dowling Slumming in New York (2009) 68 Peck accuses Crane of rhyparography—creating distasteful imagery for its own sake.

Etymology: formed as vespertilionine adj. + -ize suffix.
Previous versions of the OED give the stress as: vesperˈtilionize.
content.citations: 1854 C. D. Badham Prose Halieutics 451 Others..have vespertilionized this skate into the Sea-bat.

content.etymology:
Etymology: < Latin hederiger ivy-bearing + -ent suffix, after Latin gerent-em bearing.
Previous versions of the OED give the stress as: hedeˈrigerent.
content.citations: 1871 M. Collins Marquis & Merchant III. iii. 96 The hederigerent Maenads of old. a1876 M. Collins Thoughts in Garden (1880) I. 269 Nymphs, hederigerant, wine that's refrigerant, These are the joy of the poets and gods.
content.source: Extracted from online OED. (First seen in Foyle's Philavery. A treasury of unusual words.)

content.text: The mountain featured in the logo for Paramount Pictures is Artesonraju, in the mountain range Cordillera Blanco, in the Peruvian Andes. It has an elevation of 19,625 feet, or 6025 meters.

From developer.mozilla.org, optional chaining (?.) "permits reading the value of a property located deep within a chain of connected objects without having to expressly validate that each reference in the chain is valid."

Example: zip = person?.address?.zip; // doesn't generate an error if person hasn't yet been defined.

This was with Docker.

docker image | grep pdftron | awk '{print $3}' | xargs docker rmi

docker image provides a list of docker images.
grep filters just image entries including the specified string.
awk grabs just the specified column from each row (column 3 in this case).
xargs takes the space / newline-delimited list and passes each item as a concluding argument to the command that follows (docker rmi).

The command gets a list of images with the specified string in the name, extracts the ID of each, and deletes that image.

content.definition: A proposal tending to make peace; an attempt to reconcile differences.
content.etymology: Etymology: < Greek εἰρηνικόν, neuter of εἰρηνικός : see eirenic adj.
content.citations: [1656 (title) Εἰρηνικόν, a Poeme, wherein is persuaded the composing of the differences of all the faithfull.] 1865 E. B. Pusey Eirenicon (title page) The Church of England a Portion of Christ's One Holy Catholic Church, and a Means of restoring visible Unity: An Eirenicon. 1886 Pall Mall Gaz. 19 June 1/2 We wait with interest to see Mr. Chamberlain's response to the new Eirenicon.

content.definition:
a. A pattern used for planting trees in which they are arranged in one or more groups of five, so placed that four occupy the corners of a square or rectangle and the fifth occupies its centre; a group or plantation of trees laid out in this manner.Early texts interpret the pattern in various ways. The second edition of Elyot's Dict. (1542) provides a diagram consisting of two rows of eight circles, between which is a row of seven. The following edition ( Bibliotheca Eliotae, 1545) changes the diagram to two rows of six circles, between which is one of five. The diagram in Huloet's Dictionary (see quot. 1552) consists of a square of five rows of five diamonds, while Thomas Cooper's Thes. Linguae Romanae & Britannicae (1565) illustrates the pattern as three rows of five circles separated by two rows of four.
b. In extended use: an arrangement of five objects in this pattern; a set of five so arranged.
c. Botany. A quincuncial arrangement of leaves or perianth segments. Cf. quincuncial adj. 2. rare.
2. Astrology and (formerly) Astronomy. The aspect of two planets which are at an angular distance of five-twelfths of a circle (150 degrees) apart in the sky.
†3. Church History. A reliquary having a folding construction on a quincuncial pattern. Obsolete. rare.
in quincunx: so as to form a quincunx, in quincunx formation.
attributive, as quincunx arrangement, quincunx aestivation , quincunx fashion, quincunx form, quincunx order, etc.
content.etymology:
Etymology: < classical Latin quincunc-, quincunx five twelfths, five twelfths of a pound, five twelfths of an as, coin of this value (occasionally marked with a pattern resembling the five spots on a dice cube), pattern of this type (used of the arrangement of trees, etc.) < quīnque five (see quinque- comb. form) + uncia a twelfth (see ounce n.1). Compare French quinconce , †quinconche (1534 in Middle French as quincunce ), Italian quinconce , quincunce (a1597). Compare slightly earlier quincuncial adj.
Latin quincunx occurs earlier in an English context. Compare the following use apparently with reference to a v-shaped figure:
1545 Bibliotheca Eliotæ Decusis, tenne hole partes or ten Asses...It is also a fourme in any thynge representyng the letter, X, whiche parted in the middel, maketh an other figure called Quincunx, V.
Compare the following uses in the sense ‘five-twelfths of a pound or as’:
OE Byrhtferð Enchiridion (Ashm.) (1995) iii. 3. 184 Gyf þu todælst on syx þæt pund, þonne hatte se syxta dæl sextans and þa fife quincunx oððe cincus.
1574 G. Baker tr. Composition Oleum Magistrale f. 50v Quincunx is 5. vunces.
In form quinquonce probably after French quinconce.
content.citations: 1545 Bibliotheca Eliotæ Decusis, tenne hole partes or ten Asses...It is also a fourme in any thynge representyng the letter, X, whiche parted in the middel, maketh an other figure called Quincunx, V.

content.definition: The Mexican hairless dog. Cf. xolo n.There was much early confusion as to which animal was referred to by Hernández in 1651 (see etymology); as the name of a breed of dog, rare before the mid 20th cent.
content.etymology:
Etymology: < Nahuatl xōlōitzcuīntli (recorded in a Latin context in F. Hernández Rerum Medicarum Thes. (1651) 479), apparently < xōlō-, xōlōtl, of uncertain sense and etymology, perhaps ‘page, male servant’ + itzcuīntli particular kind of dog.
Compare Spanish xoloitzcuintli (1780; now also xoloitzcuintle).
content.citations: 1780 W. Smellie tr. Comte de Buffon Nat. Hist. Gen. & Particular VIII. 264 The proof is still farther corroborated by the circumstance of this animal's having no American name: Fernandes gives it the borrowed one of Xoloitzcuintli, which is the name of the Mexican wolf. 1850 E. C. Otté & H. G. Bohn tr. A. von Humboldt Views of Nature 87 Among the animals indigenous to Mexico, there was a very large, totally hairless, and dog-like wolf, named Xoloitzcuintli. 1929 Jrnl. Mammalogy 10 165 The name Canis mexicanus Linnaeus, based on the ‘Xoloitzcuintli’ of Hernandez.., has been shown by Glover M. Allen..to apply to the domesticated Mexican ‘hairless’ dog. 1961 Man 61 77/1 There [is]..a description and illustrations of the hairless xoloitxcuintli breed, recently established and now registered with the Mexican and American kennel clubs. 1991 Dog Fancy Jan. 94/3 (advt.) Xoloitzcuintli Hairless Puppies! Very rare, ancient, lovable!..Xolo owners rave about these almost human, faithful companions! 2012 Wall St. Jrnl. 28–29 Jan. c4/1 The Xoloitzcuintli is the national dog of Mexico... You can call them ‘Xolos’.

content.etymology: Old English þéosternes, etc., < þéostre, thester adj. + -ness suffix

c1175   Ormulum (Burchfield transcript) l. 16737   & menn ne lufenn nohht te lihht Acc lufenn þessterrnesse.

▸ c1300   Havelok (Laud) (1868) 2191   Gon was þisternesse of þe nith.
a1325  (▸c1250)    Gen. & Exod. (1968) l. 1942   Ðor-quiles he slep, In ðis ðisternesse old and dep.
1377   W. Langland Piers Plowman B. xvi. 160   On a thoresday in thesternesse þus was he taken.
?a1500   Chester Pl. ii. 12   Twynned shalbe throughe my mighte the lighte from Thesternes.

data.title: Linux Command: cp to replace existing directory

content.text:
You have two directories: ./dest and ./source/build, and you want to replace ./dest with the contents of ./source/build.

If you issue the command cp -r source/build/ dest, you will get build copied as a subdirectory of dest: ./dest/build.

What you should do instead is cp -r source/build/* dest. The addition of the asterisk will copy the contents of the build directory into the dest directory.

data.title: (a^n + 1) is a multiple of (a + 1), when n is odd.

content.text:
So I just noticed this. I was fiddling with something else, when it occurred to me that 2^3 + 1 is divisible by 2 + 1. Curious, I thought. Then I checked 3^3 + 1; and, sure enough: divisible by 3 + 1.

After testing a few more examples, I decided to see if I could prove whether this must happen consistently. So... Algebra. Sort of. I tried dividing a^n + 1 by a + 1 and found that, yes: when n is odd, the division does appear to resolve without a remainder.

Anyhow, I thought it was kind of cool.

content.definition: Of or relating to a gallows; reminiscent or suggestive of the gallows or hanging.
content.etymology: < classical Latin patibulum patible n. + -ary suffix. Compare French patibulaire (1395 in Middle French). Chiefly humorous. Now rare.
content.citations:
1646 Sir T. Browne Pseudodoxia Epidemica (1686) v. xxi. 216 Some patibulary affixion after he was slain.

1697 J. Dennis Plot & no Plot v. 64 When he came to be examin'd, he never so much as look'd once up upon me. I never saw a more patibulary phyz.

1706 tr. H. Schopperus Crafty Courtier i. xxii. 89 Ah dire patibulary Sight! Ah dismal case of Mortal Wight!

1762 O. Goldsmith Citizen of World II. 93 One was charmed with the unwashed beauties of Dung; another was captivated with the patibulary aspect of Turnip.

1801 Sporting Mag. 17 155 A certain Corn-Buyer, which had..undergone the discipline of a patibulary suspension on a gallows.

content.text:
On the origin, you need an id_rsa and an id_rsa.pub file. These are your private and public keys. Typically, you'll store them in your $HOME/.ssh directory.

On the destination, you'll need to add the contents of your id_rsa.pub file to the authorized_keys file, which is found in the $HOME/.ssh directory.

If you need to generate the private and public key files, use the ssh-keygen command:

ssh-keygen -t rsa should do it.

content.definition: The making of a likeness, esp. the waxen effigy of a person for purposes of witchcraft.

1856 S. R. Maitland False Worship Note G. 295 All this does not appear to me to contain a full explanation of invultuation.

1897 Notes & Queries 8th ser. XI. 236, 314, 395, (heading) Invultation.
content.etymology: noun of action < medieval Latin invultuāre, invultāre (in Old French envouter, 13th cent. in Hatzfeld & Darmesteter), to make a likeness, < in- + vultus countenance, visage, likeness.

When a begging boy strips himself and goes naked into a town with a false story of being cold and stripped to move compassion and get better clothes, this is called avering.

[Kennett]
having beautiful qualities. Almost seems a synonym for pulchritude.

content.text: Returns the index in an array of the first element matching the specified conditions. This differs from the find method, which returns the actual array element or object.
